'''''To the Finland Station: A Study in the Writing and Acting of History''''' (1940) is a book by American critic and historian [[Edmund Wilson]]. The work presents the history of revolutionary thought and the birth of [[socialism]], from [[the French Revolution]] through the collaboration of [[Karl Marx|Marx]] and [[Friedrich Engels|Engels]] to the arrival of [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]] at the [[Finland Station|Finlyandsky Rail Terminal]] in [[St. Petersburg]] in 1917. ==Form and Content== Wilson "had the present book in mind for six years," {{cite news | title = Revolutions's Evolution | publisher = TIME | date = 14 October 1940 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,764850,00.html | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} which [[Robert Giroux]] edited. {{cite news | last = Lehman-Haupt | first = Christopher | title = Robert Giroux, Publisher, Dies at 94 | publisher = New York Times | date = 5 September 2008 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/05/books/06giroux.html | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} The book is divided into three sections. The first spends five of eight chapters on [[Michelet]] and then discusses the "Decline of Revolutionary Tradition" vis-a-vis [[Ernest Renan]], [[Hippolyte Taine]], and [[Anatole France]]. The second deals with Socialism and Communism in sixteen chapters. The first four chapters discuss the "Origins of Socialism" vis-a-vis [[Babeuf]], [[Claude Henri de Rouvroy, comte de Saint-Simon|Saint-Simon]], [[Charles Fourier|Fourier]] and [[Robert Owen]], and [[Enfantin]] and "American Socialists" ([[Margaret Sanger]] and [[Horace Greeley]]). The second group of twelve chapters deal mostly with the development of thought in [[Karl Marx]] in light of his influences, partnership with [[Friedrich Engels]] and opposition from [[Lassalle]] and [[Bakunin]]. The third spends six chapters, dealing two each on [[Lenin]], [[Trotsky]], and again Lenin. Important writings addressed include Lenin's "[[What Is to Be Done?]]" and Trotsky's ''[[Literature and Revolution]]'', ''[[My Life (Leon Trotsky autobiography)|My Life]]'', biography of Lenin, and ''[[The History of the Russian Revolution]]''. The book also mentions [[Eleanor Marx]], [[Nadezhda Krupskaya]], [[Annie Besant]], [[Charles Bradlaugh]] and [[Gapon]]. ==Publication== [[Harcourt, Brace & Co.]] first published this book in September 1940. {{cite web | title = To the Finland Station | publisher = Library of Congress | url = http://lccn.loc.gov/40034338 | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]'s [[Anchor Books]] imprint published a paperback edition in 1953. {{cite web | title = To the Finland Station | publisher = Library of Congress | url = http://lccn.loc.gov/53003591 | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} [[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]] published a paperback edition in 1972. {{cite web | title = To the Finland Station | publisher = Library of Congress | url = http://lccn.loc.gov/77187695 | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} The ''[[New York Review of Books]]'' published a new edition in 2003, with an introduction by [[Louis Menand]]. {{cite web | title = To the Finland Station | publisher = Library of Congress | url = http://lccn.loc.gov/2002155912 | accessdate = 10 February 2011}} Upon publication, ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' said:
Because it makes Marxist theory, aims and tactics intelligible to any literate non-Marxist mind, ''To the Finland Station'' is an invaluable book. It is an advantage that, like [[John Milton|Milton]] with the character of [[Satan]], Author Wilson is half in love with the human side of the curious specimens he describes.
